coredata.dc:title: Structure of non-uniform molecular fluids: Integrodifferential equations for the density-orientation profile
coredata.dc:creator: Gubbins, K.E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A family of integrodifferential equations are derived for the density -orientation profile, p(z1ω1), in a non-uniform molecular fluid. Three of these equations are generalizations of well-known results for simple (spherical molecule) fluids, while the remaining three apply only to molecular fluids. Applications to the gas-liquid interface are briefly discussed.

Applications to the gas-liquid interface are briefly discussed. 1. Introduction We consider an equilibrium classical fluid which is inhomogeneous in the z direction, but uniform in the x and y directions; the inhomogeneity results from some external potential field c)). If the fluid is composed of simple (argon-like) molecules the quantity of greatest theoretical interest is the molecular distribution function p(rlr-, ... rtl), which is proportional to the probability density of observing a molecule with its centre of mass at rl, another at r.,, etc. The one-body distribution function or density profile, p(rl) = p(z 1), is of particular interest and has been the subject of much recent work. Several rigorous integrodifferential equations for p(z t) can be derived; they relate p(zl) to either the pair distribution function p(rlr-)) or the pair direct correlation function c(rlr?). These equations form the starting point for many approximate theories of simple non-uniform fluids. A review of this work, together with a derivation of the integrodifferential- equations for the simple fluid case, has been given by Evans [ 1 ] . In this paper these integrodifferential equations are extended to the case of molecular fluids, in which the intermolecular potential energy depends on the molecular orientations in addition to the positions of the molecular centres. Discussion Eqs. (5). (6) and (l3)-(16) are integrodifferential equations that may be used as the basis for theories of the density-orientation profile in inhomogeneous fluids: for homogeneous fluids both sides of each of these equations vanish. Eqs. (5), (13) and (1-1) are straightforward generalizations of well-known results for fluids of simple spherical molecules [ 1,4-61, but (6), (15) and (16) are new results that should prove useful in the study of the orientational structure of non-uniform molecular fluids. If p(l2) and c(I2) are known exactly, and rJ.l is painvise additive. then each of these six equations should give the same result for p(1)_ In practice we have. at best. only approximate theories for the pair correlation functions in a non uniform fluid. These equations %viu therefore vary in their usefulness in providing information about p(I ), and calculations based on more than one of them will provide a useful consistency test. _ We make the following remarks in connection with these integrodifferential equations= (a) Eqs.
